titleInfo.title: Effects of Cognitive-Linguistic Load on Spoken Production in Persons with Post-Stroke Aphasia While Ambulating
titleInfo.subTitle: A Retrospective Study

mods:mods.abstract: It is well known that aphasia, a language disorder typically caused by stroke, negatively affects communication abilities. However, little is known about how aphasia impacts a person's talking while walking, a common dual-task scenario. This is likely because stroke survivors who have aphasia are usually excluded from dual-task studies that examine spoken production and gait abilities. However, Archer et al. (2019) recently reported walking stability and speed were significantly hindered when people with aphasia were walking and talking. The current study extended findings from Archer et al. (2019) by analyzing how spoken language production abilities were impacted when people with aphasia were walking and simultaneously completing a cognitive-linguistic task. Ten people with aphasia and 10 neurologically healthy controls participated in this study and completed standardized language testing and talking-walking dual-task activities of varying cognitive-linguistic complexity. The two groups' spoken language production did not differ during the low cognitive-linguistic load condition (walking and counting); however, the person with aphasia group was significantly less accurate and less fluent with more fillers produced during the moderate (walking and naming) and high (walking and conversation) conditions. Within the aphasia group, accuracy and speed decreased, while time talking, errors, and fillers increased across the dual-task conditions. Additionally, standardized language testing was significantly correlated with naming ability while walking. These results highlight that language production may suffer when people are aphasia are walking and engaged in a demanding cognitive-linguistic task. This finding coupled with the previous finding that gait is also likely to suffer (Archer et al., 2019) suggests that caution should be taken when a person with aphasia is walking and talking, to prevent falls and to improve communication success.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Elizabeth Madden, Professor Directing Thesis; Kaitlin Lansford, Committee Member; Lauren Bislick Wilson, Committee Member; Yunjung Kim, Committee Member.
